text:
Many thanks everyone, you have suggested many options I wasn't thinking of.
<@U85HCL7JP> I work for a self-driving car startup in Cambridge on image labelling software. Or at least I did, but in the past few months due to demos approaching we've stopped working on that and moved to shuffling data back and forth. Perhaps I have been confusing the last few months with the experience overall. Yet even when I was working on the annotation tool, I still felt hugely constrained in how I did things. (vague)
I'll continue digesting everything above and give replies, thanks again.

elements.text: Many thanks everyone, you have suggested many options I wasn't thinking of.

I work for a self-driving car startup in Cambridge on image labelling software. Or at least I did, but in the past few months due to demos approaching we've stopped working on that and moved to shuffling data back and forth. Perhaps I have been confusing the last few months with the experience overall. Yet even when I was working on the annotation tool, I still felt hugely constrained in how I did things. (vague)
I'll continue digesting everything above and give replies, thanks again.

text: Thanks, I'll think on this advice. I have tried to do this before, in a "testing the waters" type way, but I would always quickly realise that what I had in mind was too vague for me to put into words, which kinda made me give up on trying to communicate them. Writing on my blog helps them solidify, when I can. But only a small amount of it relates to things that come up at work. But it is important that I persevere on verbal communication, even though it's been really hard. I wish there were some training examples I could watch / read over and over again :stuck_out_tongue:

text:
One word: externalities. One sophont's delivery is not another one's problem.

I think I already shared this link in an earlier thread: <http://250bpm.com/blog:51>

Software is memes (in the original Richard Dawkins sense) made manifest.

The only way out of this asylum is to take control of your stack. At all levels. But alas I don't know how to make that actionable yet.

There's a very great danger that in a couple of generations kids will think software is as hard to change as atoms. No more over-the-air updates, too insecure and too hard to regulate.

text: Has PLC programming been covered or brought up here? It's a very visual process with the program being essentially a diagram. Not useful in all applications but it seems like it works for the industries it is used in.

elements.text: Has PLC programming been covered or brought up here? It's a very visual process with the program being essentially a diagram. Not useful in all applications but it seems like it works for the industries it is used in.

text:
Lots of thoughtful responses here. I'll add a couple of thoughts that hopefully haven't already been mentioned:

a) Be aware of the human need for status. It's a biological thing ( <http://news.stanford.edu/news/2007/march7/sapolskysr-030707.html>), and it's at the bottom of the Maslow hierarchy. You can survive a couple of minutes without air, a few days without food and a few months without status. But you will end up with a sort of deficiency disease.

If this seems like a possibility, short-term solutions are unfortunately difficult. Try to find status outside work. Keep getting better at your job so that you can eventually parlay it into a higher-status one. Growing older helps too.

b) If you can anticipate the Architecture Astronomy argument you can also try to address it. There's a reason Joel Spolsky's article is widely known: it's actually a valid point a lot of the time. Engage with criticism you see.

c) The thread before yours is relevant: <https://futureprogramming.slack.com/archives/C5T9GPWFL/p1537671606000100>. Independent of the relative status of developers in an organization, there's a way that all developers are disempowered today: extreme division of responsibilities leading to consensual gridlock. Creators of a library often can't make changes because their users will complain. And users often can't make changes to their dependencies because of fear of forking, unnecessary complexity due to compatibility constraints and historical artifacts.

d) Consider slacking off on side projects at work. We've all done it from time to time; a terminal window arouses less comment than a browser open to Reddit. You'll get better as a developer, which is better for your employer and also better for your future status prospects. And it'll keep you sane. Obviously juggling with responsibilities is non-trivial, but if you're currently under-performing there's not much to lose there.

As I look over my list, only d) is really actionable. c) is my research project, and who knows one day I may have a solution to propose. But hopefully seeing a few possible reasons you feel as you do will help manage your motivation and energy levels.

attachments.title: Robert Sapolsky discusses physiological effects of stress
attachments.text: Why do humans and their primate cousins get more stress-related diseases than any other member of the animal kingdom? The answer, says Stanford neuroscientist Robert Sapolsky, is that people, apes and monkeys are highly intelligent, social creatures with far too much spare time on their hands.
attachments.fallback: Stanford University: Robert Sapolsky discusses physiological effects of stress

text: The company I work for creates interactive learning media for the heavy industries. We've done a lot of work for clients with sawmills and plants, where you see a lot of PLCs and ladder logic. I'm really big into visual programming, but I find the visual aspect of PLC programming to be not especially interesting.

elements.text: The company I work for creates interactive learning media for the heavy industries. We've done a lot of work for clients with sawmills and plants, where you see a lot of PLCs and ladder logic. I'm really big into visual programming, but I find the visual aspect of PLC programming to be not especially interesting.

text: What's much more interesting to me is the relationship between hydraulic, pneumatic, and electrical systems, and the schematic representations of those systems. Schematics aren't a computer programming language (or, perhaps more accurately, configuration language) the way ladder logic is, but they are very interesting ways of representing dynamic, intricate systems in a visual medium.

elements.text: What's much more interesting to me is the relationship between hydraulic, pneumatic, and electrical systems, and the schematic representations of those systems. Schematics aren't a computer programming language (or, perhaps more accurately, configuration language) the way ladder logic is, but they are very interesting ways of representing dynamic, intricate systems in a visual medium.

text: Ladder logic would probably make a very good good case study when looking at ways of representing state spaces, alongside other visualizations of state machines.

elements.text: Ladder logic would probably make a very good good case study when looking at ways of representing state spaces, alongside other visualizations of state machines.

text: Hydraulic schematics, on the other hand, would probably be a better visual medium for capturing Turing complete behaviour.

elements.text: Hydraulic schematics, on the other hand, would probably be a better visual medium for capturing Turing complete behaviour.

text: I work with some PLC experts, so if you have any questions about that domain, ask away and I'll _relay_ the answers back to you :wink:
